body: That is incredibly useful :)  I'll close this issue as it looks like just my ignorance of the features and documentation.
@himanshug I looked at the way groupBy queries work and I think you are correct. Since they are row-based instead of column-based the filtering methods used elsewhere don't immediately apply.
@milimetric Insufficient documentation is a very real possibility.

Oh, I see, I looked at that python code.  Indexing is still happening, but the file is so huge, the recursive calls to `await_task_completion` caused just the python to error out.  My suggestion there is: instead of the recursive call, just turn it into a `while True:` loop.  You can break out of it when you need (timeout, error, etc.) and then you're not pushing calls on the stack.
@milimetric Thanks for the feedback! We had tested with some large files but I guess this bug sneaked through. We'll be sure to fix it for next release.

hey @milimetric, this is fixed in master and will be in the next imply release. Fwiw this script is not actually part of Druid so the issue would be better filed in https://github.com/implydata/distribution. But I won't blame you for that because we hadn't actually made that repo public until just now :P

Makes sense, thanks guys.

@xvrl added

Towards wrapping avro object as `Map<String, Object>`, I'm thinking maybe druid could support nested dimensions/metrics. It could be expressed like`level_0_name.level_1_name`, in `InputRow#getDimension()` and `InputRow#getLongMetric()`, it can check if the full name in the keySet, if not then check if the `level_0_name` in the keySet && `map.get("level_0_name")` is a map, and do it recursively.

So if there is a top level field named "level-0-name.level-1-name", then druid gets its value as dimensions/metrics, if there isn't the top level but a nested field `{"level_0_name": {"level_1_name": "nested_value:}}`, then druid gets the nested_value.

The cons is the ambiguity, but I think in some scenario it's acceptable?
Please check https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1858
@drcrallen @guobingkun I just merged #1638. Can we merge this one?
What is the status of this PR?
We can add add an entry at https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/distribution/pom.xml#L91 if we want this extension to be package within the Druid tarball.

@pjain1 can we resolve the merge conflicts?
@himanshug @gianm is this ready?
@xvrl I don't think this is a regression. So it doesn't have to block 0.8.2 (even though we'll probably roll it out internally very quickly)

@drcrallen is setting the readTimeout on the http client not good enough? That's supposed to help with this kind of thing, in a nicer way- the connections get closed rather than left dangling when the future times out.
The readTimeout should also be on by default, but I think the default is highish (5 or 15 minutes maybe)
Can we add some documentation in the Druid docs about using this tool?
@fjy yeah, I am working on it.
:+1:  after travis

@gianm It would be nicer, but this uses a global http client, so setting that value would require setting the global timeout. There is no hook in the `HttpClient` interface to create a clone with a custom timeout. And since it uses connection pools underneath, is it possible to change timeouts for just one type of call while using the same client?
@gianm I can cancel/interrupt the future if that would make it cleaner.
This should be present for all versions of hadoop then, right?
This tool does not interact with the interval locking right? That means you may end up with nasty race conditions if used on an active cluster.
Yeah, pretty sure the issue exists for all Hadoop.

@drcrallen I think this tool is intended to be used in a situation where someone manually wants to migrate data from one place to another or rebuild metadata store segments table. In this usecase, we would expect user to have druid cluster in a safe mode (where there are no active tasks to interfere or just bringing down the cluster).

Adding the locking to this code will increase complexity and will also require for overlord to exist for this to work.
taken care of by https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1859
@himanshug Ok, just need to make sure to clarify that in the docs
@gianm That sounds good to me.
@rasahner can this be closed then?

We can remove Floats.tryParse and use something else that's available in
older versions of Guava.

> https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/1866#issuecomment-151291099.

We could just use the core Float.parseFloat() and catch the NumberFormatException and return false, as long as we're not concerned about the performance implication of throwing/catching the exception, which is probably not a big deal since this is used at ingestion time and validation failures are the exception rather than the norm.

The reason to add new cache is to follow the "add and deprecate" method when doing features. If this was a simple modification of the prior map cache then it would make sense to just improve the prior impl. But this is essentially a re-write.

`TaskLifecycleTest.testRealtimeIndexTask:839 Task should be in Success state`

Ok, I did some benchmarking and found that the level of concurrency in a java ConcurrentHashMap DOES have a very notable influence on its performance.... in java7

But in java8 I did not find a statistically significant difference. Good job java team on that one. ConcurrentHashMap in java 8 is leaps and bounds faster than in java7

btw, I'm not sure if this actually fixes anything, so feedback on that would be appreciated. I didn't actually notice a specific weird behavior that made me change this, it just seemed like a good idea
you can use regex extraction function `.{0}(.{3}).*`, which should be faster than what you are doing
jdk8 `DruidCoordinatorTest.testCoordinatorRun:349 expected:<1> but was:<0>`
Done :)
the fact that RTR has no unit tests at all and keeps getting work done on it is starting to be a concern. I don't think it needs to block this PR.
@drcrallen the RTR does have a chunk of unit tests, maybe you're thinking of the FTR which does not really have any except for the utility functions.
@gianm probably am. In that case is it possible to get a test that looks for this case?
@drcrallen it's tough to have unit tests for races… any ideas?

Would be good to support stuff like:

`foo.bar` - bar key of the foo object
`foo[0].bar` - bar key of the first element of the foo array

Anything that doesn't exist should become null. If anything resolves into an object, it should probably also be null? I guess? (what do we do now?)

A couple of tangentially related things.

#1881 - Restorable indexing tasks (PR) - so middleManagers can be restarted similarly to realtime nodes
#1884 - Rack-aware availabilityGroup assignment (issue) - suggestion from @himanshug, to make rolling restarts batchable
The plan internally here is to use task tiers to accomplish part of this.
talked to @xvrl about this, another use case is for AWS- having half your replicas on demand and half on spot.
one use case: CONCAT(dim1, dim2) -- improvement on #1873
Dammit. I wanted to file this issue. +1
@fjy rebased with the current master
A few minor comments, but I am :+1:

Just to be clear, as you can see here: https://github.com/implydata/plywood/blob/master/src/external/druidExternal.ts#L7 

it is pretty easy to do this hacky time parting for:

SECOND_OF_MINUTE: "s",
MINUTE_OF_HOUR: "m",
HOUR_OF_DAY: "H",
DAY_OF_WEEK: "e",
DAY_OF_MONTH: "d",
DAY_OF_YEAR: "D",
WEEK_OF_YEAR: "w"

Just because there happen to make sense in the time formatting usecase but something like SECOND_OF_WEEK requires some bending over backwards.

The docs for the regex extraction function state: "Returns the first matching group for the given regular expression. If there is no match, it returns the dimension value as is."

Your suggestion would work when index is 0 i.e. `(.{x}).*` where x is length (I will prob add that). But it would not work in general for index > 0. since `.{9}(.{3}).*` would transform the strings of length <= 9 incorrectly to themselves (instead of `""`)

Clever regex hacks aside I think a substr would be very cool. Something akin to https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/string-functions.html#function_substr

After these changes, what is the behaviour of task logs ? 
Do they get uploaded to s3 on each restart with diff file name or the new logs will override prev logs ? 
or they get appended to the same file and finally when the task completes/fails they are uploaded to S3 ?
@vogievetsky is there a standard or documentation for another database that describes the plyql TIME_PART function, or is it something special to plyql?
